text: Thank you, Mr. Chairperson. Good morning to the Service Delivery Committee. I'll just take the report as read and just go through a few key points along the way. Thank you. So with regards to the flood hazard mapping, we're down to ready to send out the final letters to the  The circle 100 houses that will remain at risk of a flood in a one in 100 year event. We've held off sending the final letters out until January the 17th and then so we'll send them out on that date and also on that date will be when our flood hazard viewer will be available on on our intro maps.  Next, the sub regional waste water treatment plant business case is still. being finalized it's hope to get the governance group together sometime in December, but that's looking challenging. And we're currently in discussions with my nokia who are a vermo composting company.  So they take the biosolids from wastewater treatment plants and mix them with wood, sawdust, et cetera, and feed them to worms and make a good product at the end of it. So we've just started talking to them around some contracts to deal with our wastewater sludge, which will be a good outcome. Claire, did you have a question there? Yes, yes, I did, actually.

text: I'm really interested in that, and I wondered whether or not there's any possibility that they might do that composting on site. text: Yeah, no, so it's transported to their premises in Tokoroa, and they're currently looking at establishing another facility somewhere mid between Matamata and Cambridge. They're busy setting up their systems and we've been working with them, testing their systems. So that's early days there. And so it'll be interesting to see how they go once they're fully established. So they have recruited key people and they've got one employee in Hamilton at the moment who comes from an investigation background. So that could show where their intentions lie.  On section three on water demand, so currently we're following fairly typical demand patterns. The new parallel road treatment plant is fully supplying the Pukurimu scheme and is also supplying Tiamutu via Taylor's Hill Reservoir. We'll talk about that a bit later. There's still a couple of issues around the sand and grit, but I'll talk about them when we get to the project side.  And then on section four, demand management activities, the rainwater harvesting. Again, that's been severely impacted by COVID-19 as it was all about getting out into the schools and communicating that way. So we're hoping that we can start that in the new year. Once we're at the traffic lights and schools are ready to welcome visitors. And section 4.3, the summer campaign.  So that started, hopefully you've seen our new signs out and about on the on the streets around the district. So again, they don't say water alert level one anymore. They say save water or save water to start that educational process rather than a restriction one. And we've also started our social media campaign on Facebook around some smart tips around saving water. That's our key focus is that education  One, Hamilton are moving to, intend to move to alert level two next week, I think. But again, we won't, we'll be staying with our educational campaign and not following them to alert level two.

text: Well, Martin, they don't have water meters. And I think we give our consumers that option and they get their water thing and see how they're going. I just, yeah, that's all I'm asking, yeah.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Yeah, but it still is a precious resource and part of our concerns around our water takes, we need to do water demand management and conservation. So it's all part of the wider picture.  of conserving that water. Yeah.
speaker: martinmould

text: It's just that, you know, OK, we can save water and downstream we've got Hamilton with no meters. It seems like a crazy situation. And they just seem to be adamant, especially Dave McPherson, that water meters are a crock. But Dave himself lives in the Waikato district and he has a meters, which is a bit strange to understand.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Thank you. Yeah. Can't comment on that. No, no.  And the next section is on drinking water compliance on section 5.4. So all of our stream plants are currently compliant. We did have the one that still got the non-compliant for Pukeri Moose scheme back earlier in the year. And obviously that stays with us for the year, but currently all other schemes and plants are compliant.  And then we get to our projects. So the key alternative water supply, which is part of the DIA funding, is progressing well. We're just waiting to do the final connections at the reservoir. We're just waiting for sign off from the Heritage New Zealand and waiting for Iwi assistance from NITEL in gaining that.  So it's causing us a bit of a hold up at the moment, but hopefully that we'll be able to progress that in the new year. And the parallel road treatment plant is now operational. There is still some issues with the sanding grit. So we can only run probably at half capacity. So it's designed for 12 megalitres. We can currently run at six megalitres a day. And then we then have to stop and clean the screens out, which takes about an hour and a half.  And so currently that's how we're operating, producing six megalitres a day and then cleaning them in the morning and then doing another six megalitres. We have got another screen on order to put another screen in, which will be able to take us up to eight megalitres a day before we need to clean them. We've got a trial on the plant at the moment, trying a final solution to remove the sanding grip.  So that will probably take three or four months to get enough data to show if that will work or not.
speaker: martinmould

text: Martin, did we have the same issues before this plant, or is it this plant is drawing so much more water that we get in that sand and grit and greasing in the pipes?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: No, I think it's probably always been there. The existing Pukeremu plant was a sand bed filtration plant.  So the sand and grit didn't matter because it just went into the process and didn't cause any issues. Obviously with the new membrane plant, sand and grit is very abrasive. And so we need to remove it before it gets to the membranes. And the problem is the screen's 500 micron screens, but the sand and grit is just exactly the right size to get stuck in the screen. So the screen self-washes and should normally brush all that stuff off.  but the sand is just the right size to go in all the little tiny holes. So that's why we have to take them out and water blast them to clean them. Yeah. Okay.
speaker: martinmould

text: And so Martin, on the Greenfield site, which we've got there with the plant, do we have a, what we call a settling down period before the official handover, making sure that it's doing what it should do? How's that all going other than the screen?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Yeah, so besides the screen, yeah, we're still in the commissioning phase or handover phase.  We're operating the plant and running it and ironing out all the little bugs and issues that need solving before it's fully handed over. Yeah.

text: It's carried. Thank you. Thank you, Martin. Thank you. Are you with us again? Okay. Tab 12, submission on the Economic Regulator and Consumer Protection Three Waters. Thank you.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Thank you, Mr. Chair. I'll just give a little bit of an outline, I guess, to the background of this proposed submission. So the discussion document on the economic regulator was released by MBIE a few weeks ago, and it poses three, generally three sort of areas for questions.  Now, is there a case for an economic regulator? And if so, who should be regulated across the sector? What form of regulation should that entail? And what key features should the regulation have? And then moving through that, who should be regulated and then who should fund the regulator?  So the discussion document around the economic regulator is based on the proposed three water reforms. So we're preparing a submission on the basis of, I guess, a no regrets type submission, which I know we've referred to a few times through this process that whilst, you know,  We've got significant concerns with the reform around it that this regulator, if those reforms do in fact occur, we see the regulator as an important part of that wider governance arrangements in terms of protecting consumers.  So, yeah, the discussion points sort of cover off minimum service level type requirements that the entities would be required to provide and the consumer protection mechanisms. Just to be clear, I guess, and Martin alluded to it in his report around Tamata Arawai, who's obviously now been in operation since the 15th or so of November.  that as a regulator, they are very much focused on the quality of the water delivered, both from a safety of the water, meeting all of the standard compliance requirements.  For them, there is no cost tension around that regulatory framework that they have. They just specify the minimum standards. So hence why in the submission, it suggested that having an economic regulator is an appropriate mechanism to have in that wider arrangement in terms of keeping that balance, in terms of understanding what the consumer will be receiving in terms of a service, but also at what cost.  And also in the submission, you'll see a customer charter is also highly supported as an appropriate mechanism, again, in support. Within the discussion document, there is questions posed around the mechanisms of information disclosure versus price quality regulation.  And given the fact that council really operates within that framework at the moment, the LGA sort of in terms of pursuing efficient delivery of services, but we also have the DIA with the mandatory non-financial performance measures who require us to disclose our outcomes with respect to those. So we see both of those areas as staff being really important in terms of being a part of the regulatory framework.  So it's a fairly weighty document, but as I say, it's something that we feel as staff and you'll see in the draft submission that only the water services entities should be regulated, though, acknowledging that there are a significant number and the number seems to keep growing in terms of private water suppliers.  you know, this arrangement where there is a single bore or something supplying a number of houses across a farm or across a small area. We feel that generally those sorts of relationships tend to operate well. They're generally small. There is a collective type understanding around how they're managed.  that adding a layer of bureaucracy and regulatory requirements adds no value in that space and becomes, you know, ridiculously onerous. So therefore, it is just the water services entities that we feel that needs to be included in the regulatory regime.  But yeah, we'll welcome any questions or any comments with respect to the submissions. Submission closes on the 20th, so we've still got some time if there is some feedback or commentary that elected members would like to be included. I thought it was a very good submission and I took particular interest in the questions they were answering and the answers that you gave.
speaker: dawninglis

text: I thought it fitted in quite well. Good. Any more questions from the team? Bill and Claire.  Got you. Thanks, Claire.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Oh, okay. Thanks. Yeah. Yes, Dawn, I agree too. It's a great submission and you covered things really well. I guess one of my concerns is that the definition of efficiency, that it should be focused more on customers or consumers rather than the entity itself because  I feel that there's a distinction between what might be efficient for a large-scale water entity compared to consumers. And I suppose that has a bearing on their level of consultation and also on the processes or the mechanisms that are put into the hardware of the system that might make it great for a large-scale water entity, but might have impacts for the end user, I guess. But I'm not really sure.  how to incorporate that, but on page four of the submission or page 244 of the agenda, there's a question three, what are your views on whether the entity should be regulated? And you do make the point that defining the efficiencies is important. Yeah, I'm not sure. So there's that side of it. And then on page 16, it talks about  That's page 274 of our agenda. It talks about what is price quality regulation. And there's a figure three there, and it covers building blocks and things like that. And it talks about depreciation there, and the weighted cost of average. The weighted average cost of capital  So I was really surprised to see that there, because that was a question that I raised with the DIA in the original WICS material, because they did talk about a commercial imperative for the WECs. And one of those is to achieve a return on the cost of capital from your assets. And I was told that that had been removed, that there wouldn't be a requirement to achieve.  a return on cost of capital, because that would be inappropriate. And in fact, councils do not do that in their business model. And so I thought that there'd have to be sort of slicing and dicing of parts of the business where they might want to get a return on capital for maybe new infrastructure, because there would be servicing requirements there.  I don't know, I think they should just cover their costs really and not get a return. I mean, they're actually getting the free use of our assets. They're not having to buy them. So I just thought that there needs to be a bit of care around that or City make it explicit that we need to make sure the regulator is across it. Yeah.  And then with depreciation, I'm also aware that Wix were recommending that depreciation should be collected at 120% of the cost of the assets. And again, that's a change to our business model. Yeah, and so they do recognize depreciation as a free revenue source.  Yeah, and some of the material that I read about Canada, there were some questions raised as to why so much depreciation was collected and then left in the bank accounts. Yeah, so it looks like they're expecting, there's the assumption that depreciation will actually be spent pretty much as soon as it's collected on stuff, but not necessarily on the assets that the depreciation was charged against because, you know,  renewals are lumpy and stuff like that. Yeah, so I just, I don't know whether or not we could sort of say we'd like to have more transparency about the formulas and the treatment, you know, like what would happen to the funding that was collected through depreciation. Yeah, because even though dividends aren't sort of on the table,  but there are other sort of monopolistic inefficiencies that could arise perhaps through inflated project costs or staff costs or other ways that in the end mean that prices are higher than they need to be or consumers are disadvantaged.  Gordon, what do we usually appreciate on our water assets?
speaker: clairestpierre

text: I mean, I think your electric pumps will be different to your pipes in the ground and your concrete and everything, but that seems extraordinarily high to me as well, yeah.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Yeah, no, absolutely. You're spot on, Councillor, with respect to our current depreciation as we depreciate our known assets. So I guess it's if you have a high level of uncertainty around your known assets and if you haven't got them within your database, then you may say, well, we'll over depreciate on the basis that we've got a lot of assets that we just don't know about yet.  And across the pan region of the water services entity, that may be the case for some, but no, it's points well made. I certainly will look to reinforce around activity management framework being, I believe, very important in terms of incorporated into here and all of those aspects of the activity management sort of life cycle of asset management and the like, and that an economic regulator can help support those.  Yeah, I'll just, just one minor point to add to that is that when you're looking at that figure three and how I suppose new assets are financed, I think that we also should understand if there is a ratio that's employed that might say it's a split between user charges, development contributions and debt.
speaker: dawninglis

text: so that there isn't an assumption that it's all on debt. It is covered in there that only 70% of the financing of the business is from user charges, but it's never actually been explained where the other 30% comes from. Yeah, yeah. So yeah, those are my points. Thank you very much.

text: So thanks. Thanks. I understand that now. Great. If I can go to 10D then. I was a little concerned with the first part of that statement. Our council does not have a view  on how the Treaty of Waitangi principles should be factored into the regulatory regime. So I did wonder where that view came from. Is that a view by staff? Is that a view by, because I don't know that that view has ever been to Ngāiwi tōpou,  I've never been asked to make comment on that view. I would certainly think, and have made statements previously about, I think the treaty should work through all of the work that we're doing at Council. And, you know, my participation in this committee is, you know, as a Council practising partnership.  in participation. So I did wonder about that. And it seems to be a little bit of difference. That statement seems to be a little bit of difference to, I think it's number 27.  It is number 27 where we say our council believes that all Taritia Waitangi principles should be hacked into the regulatory regime, including consumer protection rights. So I did wonder why we were taking a different position in regards to economic regulation as opposed to consumer regulations.  And I do think that the decisions we've got coming out in terms of the airwaves and, you know, that's why I briefly spoke about the telecommunications 2001 legislation. I think that Aotearoa has moved significantly since that legislation was put into place in terms of Treaty principles.  Those key ones being partnership protection and participation. And I did wonder whether you know whether there should be some information in that regard. And as I said, I think that there's a difference between what we're saying in 10D and what we're saying in 27.

text: Through the chair, I possibly have not, I guess, put it as well as I could have, I guess. With respect to 10D, it was more, excuse me, the how those principles.
